html:
@flamingbear environment.yml is like requirements.txt and allows you a way to install all of the requirements you may need including pip ones.

However, if you want packages, you need to create packages for all of your python requirements. There are helper tools though like conda skeleton pypi, which constructs a recipe for a package on PyPI. Using the --recursive option, you can get recipes for all dependencies, as well.
text:
@flamingbear `environment.yml` is like `requirements.txt` and allows you a way to install all of the requirements you may need including `pip` ones.

However, if you want packages, you need to create packages for all of your python requirements. There are helper tools though like `conda skeleton pypi`, which constructs a recipe for a package on PyPI. Using the `--recursive` option, you can get recipes for all dependencies, as well.

html:
Hi Everybody,
I’m banging my head against conda features and I’m not sure what the best path forward is.
The short is as follow:
We use vtk. We have two option for Linux when building vtk with or without mesalib.
Mesalib is already in conda-forge (thanks) and has the “mesalib” track_feature on.
Now I don’t understand how to tell the recipe to build both possible version the “regular” one and the one with the mesalib option.
I see numpy provide the openblas feature and you go back to a regular numpy if you yank openblas.
I would like my users to be able to choose if they want this feature or not.
The problem propagates further as we have many package which are pure python that rely on the “vtk” package, for these, the code is identical they do not care, so I’m assuming we could just add “Vtk” as a requirement correct?
Ideally I would like the default to come w/o the measlib feature and if the user decides to install mesalib then have automatically vtk being updated to the vtk-mesalib feature enabled.
Thanks for any pointers
text:
Hi Everybody,
I’m banging my head against conda features and I’m not sure what the best path forward is.
The short is as follow:
We use vtk. We have two option for Linux when building vtk with or without mesalib.
Mesalib is already in conda-forge (thanks) and has the “mesalib” track_feature on.
Now I don’t understand how to tell the recipe to build both possible version the “regular” one and the one with the mesalib option.
I see numpy provide the openblas feature and you go back to a regular numpy if you yank openblas.
I would like my users to be able to choose if they want this feature or not.
The problem propagates further as we have many package which are pure python that rely on the “vtk” package, for these, the code is identical they do not care, so I’m assuming we could just add “Vtk” as a requirement correct?
Ideally I would like the default to come w/o the measlib feature and if the user decides to install mesalib then have automatically vtk being updated to the vtk-mesalib feature enabled.
Thanks for any pointers

When building a Python package I can get the version from my setup.py using jinja templating in the meta.yaml file:

{% set data = load_setup_py_data() %}

Is there an equivalent for building R packages to set the Version in the DESCRIPTION file?
text:
When building a Python package I can get the version from my `setup.py` using jinja templating in the `meta.yaml` file:
```
{% set data = load_setup_py_data() %}
```
Is there an equivalent for building R packages to set the Version in the `DESCRIPTION` file?

html: @dhirschfeld not currently, but I'd be happy to have it. Got time for a PR? I think it should be simple - just look at the load_setup_py_data function in jinja_context.py
text: @dhirschfeld not currently, but I'd be happy to have it.  Got time for a PR?  I think it should be simple - just look at the load_setup_py_data function in jinja_context.py

html: You'll also need to connect that into the jinja context in the context_processor function at the bottom of jinja_context.py
text: You'll also need to connect that into the jinja context in the context_processor function at the bottom of jinja_context.py

html: Thanks for the pointers - it'll certainly be better to do it properly rather than hack together some ugly workaround. Unfortunately, its fairly far down my list of priorities - I was hoping there was already something ready-rolled since Anaconda publish R packages already.

text: Hi all, I'm building a conda package and my `meta.yaml` includes the import test `imports: mypackage`. This was building and passing fine until I reordered my channel priorities (moved `default` up from the bottom). I wasn't expecting any interaction between these. Is this expected?

html: channel priority affects which packages get used, so yeah, it's totally conceivable that things could break.  Mostly, they'd break because something from defaults is incompatible for some reason, though.  We'd like to know which package is giving you issues

+ ct-ng x86_64-centos6-linux-gnu
make: *** No rule to make target 'x86_64-centos6-linux-gnu'.  Stop.

I modified build.sh slightly to list the samples and these are all the x86_64 samples available

[G..]   x86_64-multilib-linux-gnu
[G.X]   x86_64-multilib-linux-musl
[G..]   x86_64-multilib-linux-uclibc
[G.X]   x86_64-w64-mingw32,x86_64-pc-linux-gnu
[G..]   x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu
[G..]   x86_64-unknown-linux-uclibc
[G.X]   x86_64-w64-mingw32

I tried my system ct-ng installation and the x86_64-centos6-linux-gnu sample is present there. The x86_64-centos6-linux-gnu doesn't seem to be distributed with the crosstool-ng-1.22.0-403-geff79ab7-0 package.
text:
@msarahan I was attempting to reproduce a gcc 7.2.0 build from https://github.com/AnacondaRecipes/aggregate/tree/master/ctng-compilers-feedstock/recipe and was running into a ct-ng configuration issue (https://github.com/AnacondaRecipes/aggregate/blob/master/ctng-compilers-feedstock/recipe/build.sh#L65)
```
+ ct-ng x86_64-centos6-linux-gnu
make: *** No rule to make target 'x86_64-centos6-linux-gnu'.  Stop.
```

```
[G..]   x86_64-multilib-linux-gnu
[G.X]   x86_64-multilib-linux-musl
[G..]   x86_64-multilib-linux-uclibc
```

 I tried my system ct-ng installation and the x86_64-centos6-linux-gnu sample is present there.  The x86_64-centos6-linux-gnu doesn't seem to be distributed with the crosstool-ng-1.22.0-403-geff79ab7-0 package.

html: Hi all! I'm not sure if I'm missing something quite stupid. I'm trying to compile some C++ code in my build.sh. I need to link against openblas using -lopenblas. I've added openblas to my meta.yaml so that if I $ ls $PREFIX/lib in the build script I see the openblas libs there. However, when I compile and link my code, it cannot find the library.
text: Hi all! I'm not sure if I'm missing something quite stupid. I'm trying to compile some C++ code in my `build.sh`. I need to link against openblas using `-lopenblas`. I've added `openblas` to my `meta.yaml` so that if I `$ ls $PREFIX/lib` in the build script I see the openblas libs there. However, when I compile and link my code, it cannot find the library.

html: Am I wrong to assume that $PREFIX/lib is the default lookup for libraries?
text: Am I wrong to assume that `$PREFIX/lib` is the default lookup for libraries?

html: It seems I was wrong to assume! I've added -L$(PREFIX)/lib to my linker line and it's now working.
text: It seems I was wrong to assume! I've added `-L$(PREFIX)/lib` to my linker line and it's now working.

html:
Yup, this is what was confusing to me!

It is my understanding that using something like {{ cdt('libxrender-devel') }}creates a folder librsvg_XXXX/_build_env/x86_64-conda_cos6-linux-gnu/sysroot/user/lib64 with the required libraries. However, the folder that gets appended to LDFLAGS, etc. is librsvg_XXXX/_h_env_placehold_placehold..../lib, which does not contain any of the libraries in x86_64-conda_cos6-linux-gnu/sysroot/user/lib64.

Maybe a better example of this is the second build which I am having trouble with: gobject (https://gitlab.com/ostrokach-forge/pygobject/-/jobs/53546289). Sorry for the messy build log; I've been trying to debug this by tweaking things for the entire day. Basically, I added {{ cdt('libxrender-devel') }} to the build: section of the conda recipe, but the build still fails with /opt/conda/conda-bld/pygobject_1519170951873/work/tests/tmp-introspecto5husdqr/.libs/lt-Regress-1.0: error while loading shared libraries: libXrender.so.1: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory.

If I use xorg-libxrender from the conda-forge channel, the build correctly finds the libXrender.so.1 library with no further modifications.
text:
Yup, this is what was confusing to me!

It is my understanding that using something like `{{ cdt('libxrender-devel') }}`creates a folder `librsvg_XXXX/_build_env/x86_64-conda_cos6-linux-gnu/sysroot/user/lib64` with the required libraries. However, the folder that gets appended to LDFLAGS, etc. is `librsvg_XXXX/_h_env_placehold_placehold..../lib`, which does not contain any of the libraries in `x86_64-conda_cos6-linux-gnu/sysroot/user/lib64`.

Maybe a better example of this is the second build which I am having trouble with: `gobject` (https://gitlab.com/ostrokach-forge/pygobject/-/jobs/53546289).  Sorry for the messy build log; I've been trying to debug this by tweaking things for the entire day. Basically, I added `{{ cdt('libxrender-devel') }}` to the `build:` section of the conda recipe, but the build still fails with `/opt/conda/conda-bld/pygobject_1519170951873/work/tests/tmp-introspecto5husdqr/.libs/lt-Regress-1.0: error while loading shared libraries: libXrender.so.1: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory`. 

If I use `xorg-libxrender` from the conda-forge channel, the build correctly finds the `libXrender.so.1` library with no further modifications.

html: my understanding (which is not great; @mingwandroid is the one who understands this better) is that the compiler's internal paths should point to that x86_64-conda_cos6-linux-gnu/sysroot/user/lib64 folder (also known as a sysroot). You should not need any recipe modification. I hope that Ray can help clarify what's going wrong here.
text: my understanding (which is not great; @mingwandroid is the one who understands this better) is that the compiler's internal paths should point to that ``x86_64-conda_cos6-linux-gnu/sysroot/user/lib64`` folder (also known as a sysroot).  You should not need any recipe modification.  I hope that Ray can help clarify what's going wrong here.

html: I see. Yes, if you have inter-dependent builds, you can't use --croot without also managing your artifact availability somehow. It should be reasonable to modify https://github.com/conda/conda-build/blob/717d04ae8ae65ab73b7eb8fedd0d37a84cad69a5/conda_build/build.py#L2300 to filter the folder list based on the current lock list. Locks are located in <PREFIX>/locks, and the lock name is the base64 encoded path: https://github.com/conda/conda-build/blob/master/conda_build/utils.py#L550
text: I see.  Yes, if you have inter-dependent builds, you can't use --croot without also managing your artifact availability somehow. html: Does CMake really need to know which conda pkg provides which library? Provided it’s installed (requirements:host) in $PREFIX, often CMake’s own detection mechanisms find the libraries, and if not, you can provide it hints (e.g., HDF5_LIBRARIES=$PREFIX/lib/libhdf5.so or PROJECT_DIR=$PREFIX/share/cmake/PROJECT)
text: Does CMake really need to know which conda pkg provides which library? Provided it’s installed (`requirements:host`) in `$PREFIX`, often CMake’s own detection mechanisms find the libraries, and if not, you can provide it hints (e.g., `HDF5_LIBRARIES=$PREFIX/lib/libhdf5.so` or `PROJECT_DIR=$PREFIX/share/cmake/PROJECT`)

html:
@dharhas you need to do something like:
build:
  skip: True  # [win and vc > 9]
  ignore_run_exports:
    - vc

requirements:
  build:
    - {{ compiler('c') }}
  run:
    - vs2008_runtime   # [win]
text:
@dharhas you need to do something like:

```
build:
  skip: True  # [win and vc > 9]
  ignore_run_exports:
    - vc

requirements:
  build:
    - {{ compiler('c') }}
  run:
    - vs2008_runtime   # [win]
```

html: there are several parts there.
text: there are several parts there.

html: first, you only build on vc9
text: first, you only build on vc9

html: next, you want to bypass the vc package as a run_export, because it is what enforces mutual exclusivity and prevents you from using it with py3
text: next, you want to bypass the vc package as a run_export, because it is what enforces mutual exclusivity and prevents you from using it with py3

html: note that you are mixing runtimes, which is not advisable
text: note that you are mixing runtimes, which is not advisable

html: finally, the compiler stuff stays the same, but you manually add the runtime requirement that would otherwise be provided by the vc provided by run_exports
text: finally, the compiler stuff stays the same, but you manually add the runtime requirement that would otherwise be provided by the vc provided by run_exports

html: Interesting that you have something that builds with vs 2008 but not newer - usually it's the other way around
text: Interesting that you have something that builds with vs 2008 but not newer - usually it's the other way around

html: either way, we don't ever mix runtimes for packages at Anaconda.  We used to, but it's not worth it for us because the bugs can be very bad/subtle
text: either way, we don't ever mix runtimes for packages at Anaconda.  We used to, but it's not worth it for us because the bugs can be very bad/subtle

html: I'm working on a package that depends on boost and needs to be compiled with the c++11 standard libraries.  However, it looks like primary boost libraries packaged in conda were not build with c++11 support. Is there another boost package that has c++11 support?
text: I'm working on a package that depends on boost and needs to be compiled with the c++11 standard libraries.  However, it looks like primary boost libraries packaged in conda were not build with c++11 support. Is there another boost package that has c++11 support?

html:
@swainn you might be getting conda-forge packages confused with the Anaconda packages. All of Anaconda's packages are built with very new compilers and have C++11 support, as well as 14 and some 17. More details at https://www.anaconda.com/blog/developer-blog/utilizing-the-new-compilers-in-anaconda-distribution-5/?lang=en-us

You must be sure that your boost packages are coming from repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/main, aka defaults.
text:
@swainn you might be getting conda-forge packages confused with the Anaconda packages.  All of Anaconda's packages are built with very new compilers and have C++11 support, as well as 14 and some 17.  More details at https://www.anaconda.com/blog/developer-blog/utilizing-the-new-compilers-in-anaconda-distribution-5/?lang=en-us

You must be sure that your boost packages are coming from repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/main, aka defaults.

html: @msarahan Thank you, I was indeed using conda-forge boost. Switching to using the default repo got the build working.
text: @msarahan Thank you, I was indeed using conda-forge boost. Switching to using the default repo got the build working.

html:
@msarahan, I have a couple of quick questions regarding the API:
  • Is it fine to use a single conda_build.config.Config instance while batch-processing/-rendering recipes? Or does it get modified while rendering such that it is best to use a new instance for each recipe?
  • Would you accept a PR to extend either the --exclusive-config-file CLI parameter or the conda_build: config_file .condarc parameter to accept multiple paths?
    The use case is Bioconda which is essentially a conda-forge downstream repository now. As such we want to use conda-forge-pinning's conda_build_config.yaml but also add our own on top of that. Using --variant-files won't work, due to the config file processing order, as soon as we would start to add per-recipe configuration files.
  • I noticed that exclusive_config_file and conda_build: config_file/~/conda_build_config.yaml are parsed over and over again in batch-processing recipes (for every call of variants.get_package_variants). Would it be possible to cache their parsed contents somewhere? I think caching that should be fine since it's the "bottom configuration" and doesn't depend on anything in the recipe, right?
text:
@msarahan, I have a couple of quick questions regarding the API:
- Is it fine to use a single `conda_build.config.Config` instance while batch-processing/-rendering recipes? Or does it get modified while rendering such that it is best to use a new instance for each recipe?
- Would you accept a PR to extend either the `--exclusive-config-file` CLI parameter or the `conda_build: config_file` `.condarc` parameter to accept multiple paths?
  The use case is Bioconda which is essentially a conda-forge downstream repository now. As such we want to use `conda-forge-pinning`'s `conda_build_config.yaml` but also add our own on top of that. Using `--variant-files` won't  work, due to the config file processing order, as soon as we would start to add per-recipe configuration files.
- I noticed that `exclusive_config_file` and `conda_build: config_file`/`~/conda_build_config.yaml` are parsed over and over again in batch-processing recipes (for every call of `variants.get_package_variants`). Would it be possible to cache their parsed contents somewhere? I think caching that should be fine since it's the "bottom configuration" and doesn't depend on anything in the recipe, right?

html: @marcelotrevisani, do you have any conda_build_config.yaml file that might override the default values for the compiler(...) function? E.g., the config file from conda-forge-pinning will replace them in way you'll get your system's GCC instead.
text: @marcelotrevisani, do you have any `conda_build_config.yaml` file that might override the default values for the `compiler(...)` function? E.g., the config file from `conda-forge-pinning` will replace them in way you'll get your system's GCC instead.

Conda takes a pretty long while to figure out the dependencies

most time by far is spent on installing the packages in temporary envs

So, is it the dependency resolution or the installation itself (i.e., the part where the log outputs "Preparing/Verifying/Executing transaction") that is taking the most time? If it's the latter, you could just use a faster storage temporarily, if you have one available (e.g., using CONDA_BLD_PATH/CONDA_PKGS_DIRS and the like). I don't think there is (or at least am not aware of) a way to reuse a build environment in the way you asked for. If you don't build often, but rather just test your Python package itself often, I'd advice to manually create an environment with the dependencies and then pip install --no-deps -e .(.=assuming your setup.py is in the CWD) your package into that environment.

html:
@msarahan, while you're here, what are your thoughts on the following (short "yes"/"no"/"yes, make PR for X" answers suffice):

@msarahan, I have a couple of quick questions regarding the API:

  • Is it fine to use a single conda_build.config.Config instance while batch-processing/-rendering recipes? Or does it get modified while rendering such that it is best to use a new instance for each recipe?
  • Would you accept a PR to extend either the --exclusive-config-file CLI parameter or the conda_build: config_file .condarc parameter to accept multiple paths?
    The use case is Bioconda which is essentially a conda-forge downstream repository now. As such we want to use conda-forge-pinning's conda_build_config.yaml but also add our own on top of that. Using --variant-files won't work, due to the config file processing order, as soon as we would start to add per-recipe configuration files.
  • I noticed that exclusive_config_file and conda_build: config_file/~/conda_build_config.yaml are parsed over and over again in batch-processing recipes (for every call of variants.get_package_variants). Would it be possible to cache their parsed contents somewhere? I think caching that should be fine since it's the "bottom configuration" and doesn't depend on anything in the recipe, right?
text:
@msarahan, while you're here, what are your thoughts on the following (short "yes"/"no"/"yes, make PR for X" answers suffice): 
> @msarahan, I have a couple of quick questions regarding the API:
- Is it fine to use a single `conda_build.config.Config` instance while batch-processing/-rendering recipes? Or does it get modified while rendering such that it is best to use a new instance for each recipe?
- Would you accept a PR to extend either the `--exclusive-config-file` CLI parameter or the `conda_build: config_file` `.condarc` parameter to accept multiple paths?
  The use case is Bioconda which is essentially a conda-forge downstream repository now. As such we want to use `conda-forge-pinning`'s `conda_build_config.yaml` but also add our own on top of that. Using `--variant-files` won't  work, due to the config file processing order, as soon as we would start to add per-recipe configuration files.
- I noticed that `exclusive_config_file` and `conda_build: config_file`/`~/conda_build_config.yaml` are parsed over and over again in batch-processing recipes (for every call of `variants.get_package_variants`). Would it be possible to cache their parsed contents somewhere? I think caching that should be fine since it's the "bottom configuration" and doesn't depend on anything in the recipe, right?

html:
@mbargull

Is it fine to use a single conda_build.config.Config instance while batch-processing/-rendering recipes? Or does it get modified while rendering such that it is best to use a new instance for each recipe?

It should be fine, but see this recent issue for maybe more info: https://github.com/conda-forge/staged-recipes/pull/5935#issuecomment-392814567

Would you accept a PR to extend either the --exclusive-config-file CLI parameter or the conda_build: config_file .condarc parameter to accept multiple paths?
The use case is Bioconda which is essentially a conda-forge downstream repository now. As such we want to use conda-forge-pinning's conda_build_config.yaml but also add our own on top of that. Using --variant-files won't work, due to the config file processing order, as soon as we would start to add per-recipe configuration files.

Sure, I think that's fine. Just be really clear what the priority is. I think it would be most consistent to have later files have higher priority (this is backwards compared to channels in conda, but more consistent with the CLI behavior, and I hope consistent with the variant config files entry in condarc).

I noticed that exclusive_config_file and conda_build: config_file/~/conda_build_config.yaml are parsed over and over again in batch-processing recipes (for every call of variants.get_package_variants). Would it be possible to cache their parsed contents somewhere? I think caching that should be fine since it's the "bottom configuration" and doesn't depend on anything in the recipe, right?

What needs to be clarified here is what the scope of selectors is for any parsed config file. If you can use variables from the file itself as selectors, it needs to be iterative. If you can only use the small set of selectors that are hard-coded, then you can cache. Maybe I'm misunderstanding your question, though. I think if the assumption is "I'm doing batch processing and these files are always the same," then yes, I'd recommend caching it, perhaps by creating the Config instance and passing that around (copying it if you find it getting mutated undesirably)

Using --variant-files won't work, due to the config file processing order, as soon as we would start to add per-recipe configuration files.

Sure, I think that's fine.  Just be really clear what the priority is.  I think it would be most consistent to have later files have higher priority (this is backwards compared to channels in conda, but more consistent with the CLI behavior, and I hope consistent with the variant config files entry in condarc).

> I noticed that exclusive_config_file and conda_build: config_file/~/conda_build_config.yaml are parsed over and over again in batch-processing recipes (for every call of variants.get_package_variants). Would it be possible to cache their parsed contents somewhere? I think caching that should be fine since it's the "bottom configuration" and doesn't depend on anything in the recipe, right?

What needs to be clarified here is  what the scope of selectors is for any parsed config file.  If you can use variables from the file itself as selectors, it needs to be iterative.  If you can only use the small set of selectors that are hard-coded, then you can cache.  Maybe I'm misunderstanding your question, though. html: PS: the .copy() method on a Config object should be helpful
text: PS: the .copy() method on a Config object should be helpful

html:
def copy(self):
    new = copy.copy(self)
    new.variant = copy.deepcopy(self.variant)
    if hasattr(self, 'variants'):
        new.variants = copy.deepcopy(self.variants)
    return new

Many thanks!

I think it would be most consistent to have later files have higher priority

Indeed, it would be conda-build -e lower-prio-config.yaml -e higher-prio-config.yaml

I think if the assumption is "I'm doing batch processing and these files are always the same,"

Correct, that's the case.

I'd recommend caching it, perhaps by creating the Config instance and passing that around (copying it if you find it getting mutated undesirably)

That's what I assumed previously to work, but conda_build.variants.get_package_variants calls conda_build.variants.find_config_files and for each of those files (which includes the exclusive_config_file) conda_build.variants.parse_config_file is called. Hence for different recipes get_package_variants does not load the parsed contents of exclusive_config_file from any cache.
I'm not too familiar with the code and thus wasn't sure where to add/find such caching.

PS: the .copy() method on a Config object should be helpful

Thanks for pointing it out, I missed that one!
text:
Many thanks!
> I think it would be most consistent to have later files have higher priority

Indeed, it would be `conda-build -e lower-prio-config.yaml -e higher-prio-config.yaml`

> I think if the assumption is "I'm doing batch processing and these files are always the same," 

Correct, that's the case.

>  I'd recommend caching it, perhaps by creating the Config instance and passing that around (copying it if you find it getting mutated undesirably)

That's what I assumed previously to work, but `conda_build.variants.get_package_variants` calls `conda_build.variants.find_config_files` and for each of those files (which includes the `exclusive_config_file`) `conda_build.variants.parse_config_file` is called. Hence for different recipes `get_package_variants` does not load the parsed contents of `exclusive_config_file` from any cache.
I'm not too familiar with the code and thus wasn't sure where to add/find such caching.

> PS: the .copy() method on a Config object should be helpful

Thanks for pointing it out, I missed that one!

I'll just use the regular CI stages for test/build management and use conda build really just for conda packaging I think.

Wise choice :wink:
I'd decouple the regular tests from the conda-build packaging in general and use the test section in meta.yaml just for fast-running sanity checks to see if the package was build successfully (e.g., tests for whether the application starts at all or is able to output help/version text, etc.). This is also the strategy for recipes in popular channels like conda-forge.
text:

I'd decouple the regular tests from the `conda-build` packaging in general and use the `test` section in `meta.yaml` just for fast-running sanity checks to see if the package was build successfully (e.g., tests for whether the application starts at all or is able to output help/version text, etc.). This is also the strategy for recipes in popular channels like conda-forge.

html: @TiemenSch we don't do anything to arbitrarily restrict builds. Conda-build actually does very little building. It really just creates environments, then runs your build script (bld.bat), and then bundles things up afterwards. For any significant build, whatever you're doing in bld.bat will dominate the total build time, and you need to investigate what in your script might be taking so long.

For any significant build, whatever you're doing in bld.bat will dominate the total build time, and you need to investigate what in your script might be taking so long.

text:
just an odd thing which is happening to me
I created a recipe in build requirements with
```
    - {{ compiler('c') }}
    - {{ compiler('cxx') }}
```

However, when I compile that it is giving me a weird error in linking phase with an older package (openmqc). The error is:
``libopenmqc.so: undefined reference to `memcpy@GLIBC_2.14'``

If a put the build requirements as:
```
    - {{ compiler('c') }}
    - {{ compiler('cxx') }}
    - toolchain
```
It will use the compiler of my machine (gcc 7.3)and the problem is solved... I also tried in another machine with gcc 7.2 and the error does not appear

html: Does anyone have a clue what's happening?
text: Does anyone have a clue what's happening?

html:
The compiler packages from Anaconda vendor glibc 2.12. This is extremely helpful to in regards to ensuring compatibility/minimum requirements for all builds compiled with those compilers. glibc 2.12 is chosen since that's the one shipped with CentOS 6, the base system requirement targeted by Ananconda.
The error you got means that the libopenmqc.so that gets used was built with a newer glibc version. It would be best to rebuilt that library with those compilers.
Adding toolchain along the {{ compiler(...) }} packages essentially negates the use of the compilers and the effort to ensure glibc 2.12 is used: the built package might require a newer glibc than the one met by the minimum CentOS 6 requirement.
text:
The compiler packages from Anaconda vendor glibc 2.12. This is extremely helpful to in regards to ensuring compatibility/minimum requirements for all builds compiled with those compilers. glibc 2.12 is chosen since that's the one shipped with CentOS 6, the base system requirement targeted by Ananconda.
The error you got means that the `libopenmqc.so` that gets used was built with a newer glibc version. It would be best to rebuilt that library with those compilers.
Adding `toolchain` along the `{{ compiler(...) }}` packages essentially negates the use of the compilers and the effort to ensure glibc 2.12 is used: the built package might require a newer glibc than the one met by the minimum CentOS 6 requirement.

html: Ah, the log is very helpful! It shows g++ -c -O2 -DLINUX ... invocations which means the g++ on PATH is used. But the Anaconda compiler packages have their binaries explicitly named, e.g., like x86_64-conda_cos6-linux-gnu-c++. Thus a g++ will not run those compilers. You should make sure the build process uses "${CC}"/"${CXX}" instead of hardcoded gcc/g++.
text: Ah, the log is very helpful! It shows `g++ -c -O2 -DLINUX  ...` invocations which means the `g++` on `PATH` is used. But the Anaconda compiler packages have their binaries explicitly named, e.g., like `x86_64-conda_cos6-linux-gnu-c++`. Thus a `g++` will not run those compilers. You should make sure the build process uses `"${CC}"`/`"${CXX}"` instead of hardcoded `gcc`/`g++`.

@msarahan. For me as an outsider, it looked like 'more of the same' to implement compared to the build/run variants, but that's just a quick gist and not based on package knowledge at all.

I also looked into tox some more and it has great extension support from what I can see. I'm planning to spend some time to get tox-conda to life! That way, conda-build could focus on what it does best (building packages) and tox, too.

Especially for pure Python there could be significant overlap in build and test environments, but if all users do in build is python -m pip install . --no-deps, then they might as well use tox up front anyway. The overhead may reduce dramatically, if tox uses the same package cache. As much as I would like a one stop shop, packages should focus on one thing and do it well :).

Yes, that is often the best approach.  I think we'll do something like what you mention, but at the CI level.  We often need to run tests on hardware that is different from the build system, so that's really out of scope for conda-build

html: Hopefully quick question on conda/windows builds.  I’m new to Windows, and need to use cython in a fall course I’m teaching to a mixed windows/macos cohort.  I’ve got a setup.py that calls cmake to build the cython extension — no problem in a Unix bash shell with the new anaconda compilers.  On windows however, I set my conda environment by launching an anaconda prompt, and a compiler environment by launching a developer command prompt for VS 2017.  Is there some way to merge these, or should I be doing something different?
text: Hopefully quick question on conda/windows builds.  I’m new to Windows, and need to use cython in a fall course I’m teaching to a mixed windows/macos cohort.  I’ve got a setup.py that calls cmake to build the cython extension — no problem in a Unix bash shell with the new anaconda compilers.  On windows however, I set my conda environment by launching an anaconda prompt, and a compiler environment by launching a developer command prompt for VS 2017.  Is there some way to merge these, or should I be doing something different?

html:
There is a vs2017 package that we haven't released yet, because of problems we've seen with vs2017 and some packages. Those problems may not affect you, though - they've been pretty detailed things in heavy C++, like Qt. https://anaconda.org/c3i_test2/vs2017_win-64

It's just activate scripts, not actual compilers. It'll replace your developer command prompt step. You will need one further customization, though. Conda-build defaults to vs2008 for python 2.7, and vs2015 for python 3.5+. The conda_build_config.yaml file can be used to change that default. The easiest thing to do is to copy the file from https://github.com/AnacondaRecipes/aggregate/blob/master/conda_build_config.yaml and change the c_compiler and cxx_compiler entries. Note that they are "zipped" with other keys. zipped fields must all have the same length, so don't delete entries arbitrarily.

html: Perhaps I didn't understand what you were doing.  conda_build_config.yaml is for conda-build.  If you do only steps 1 and 3, that should be fine for interactive use.  However, we don't use that workflow at all currently (we only use conda-build to produce packages), so you may hit some snags, such as runtime dependencies being missing.  It should be find on your students' computers, but if they try to ship their compiled stuff elsewhere, it may not work.  In that case, you'll want them to use conda-build to produce packages.  You'd remove your steps 1 and 3, write a conda recipe, and let conda-build take care of the compiler installation and environment activations.
text: Perhaps I didn't understand what you were doing.  conda_build_config.yaml is for conda-build.  If you do only steps 1 and 3, that should be fine for interactive use.  However, we don't use that workflow at all currently (we only use conda-build to produce packages), so you may hit some snags, such as runtime dependencies being missing.  It should be find on your students' computers, but if they try to ship their compiled stuff elsewhere, it may not work.  In that case, you'll want them to use conda-build to produce packages.  You'd remove your steps 1 and 3, write a conda recipe, and let conda-build take care of the compiler installation and environment activations.

html: Yes, on Linux C/CXX/Fortran come with libgomp (though Fortran doesn’t pick up as OpenMP-enabled by CMake FindOpenMP) and you can also use libiomp5 through package intel-openmp. On Mac C/CXX can use OpenMP with llvm-openmp package or intel-openmp+llvm-openmp. Fortran on Mac uses libgomp.
text: Yes, on Linux C/CXX/Fortran come with `libgomp` (though Fortran doesn’t pick up as OpenMP-enabled by CMake FindOpenMP) and you can also use `libiomp5` through package `intel-openmp`. On Mac C/CXX can use OpenMP with `llvm-openmp` package or `intel-openmp`+`llvm-openmp`. Fortran on Mac uses `libgomp`.

text: For C/Linux/gomp, no packages beyond the compilers needed. For C/Mac/omp, you need `llvm-openmp` in `requirements/build` and maybe in `requirements/run` (I put `intel-openmp` in that latter position, so I’m not entirely sure about the simpler pure-`omp` case).

html: Hi. I hope this is the right place to post this. I'm building a package with conda which uses cuda, and therefore nvcc for the build. As far as I can tell, this prevents me from using the anaconda distributed gcc/g++, as they are too new for nvcc. I'm currently building using a system gcc, but i'm worried about this leading to runtime linking different libraries (e.g., numpy links the conda libgcc and my program links the system libgcc). Whatever i'm doing currently seems to work, in that the code runs, but i'm worried about stability and subtle bugs. I wasn't able to find much guidance of this online or in the docs, and was wondering if anyone had any advice or could point me towards a resource to really nail down these issues. Thanks in advance!

html:
@stilley2 yes, correct. I see for you two options for reproducable environment:
1) Using Docker and system level compilers
2) Building your versions of compilers

if you decide following option 2, then your steps are following
1) check examples for certain versions of gcc, as here https://github.com/AnacondaRecipes/aggregate/blob/master/ctng-compilers-feedstock/recipe/conda_build_config.cos6.x86_64.gcc5.4.yaml
2) prepare your own config and use it as conda build -m <YOUR_CONFIG>
3) Use activation recipe with the same version of config

extra info for conda build config - here https://conda.io/docs/user-guide/tasks/build-packages/variants.html
for options on compilers https://crosstool-ng.github.io/ and some sample examples used in config: https://github.com/crosstool-ng/crosstool-ng/tree/master/samples

If I specify the following 

build:
    string:  abc_xyz
    number: 123
`

My expectation is to have the output file as package_name-version-abc_xyz_123.tar.bz2.

However i end up with package_name-version-abc_xyz.tar.bz2even though the meta data files in the package correctly have 123 as the build number.

If i skip setting the build string then i get the package with desired name format, but then the buildstring is one generated by conda and does not contain some custom information i want.. Is that desired feature or a bug ?
text:
If  I specify the following 
```
build:
    string:  abc_xyz
    number: 123
````
My expectation is to have the output file as `package_name-version-abc_xyz_123.tar.bz2`. 

However i end up with `package_name-version-abc_xyz.tar.bz2`even though the meta data files in the package correctly have 123 as the build number.   

If i skip setting the build string then i get the package with desired name format, but then the buildstring is one generated by conda and does not contain some custom information i want.. Is that desired feature or a bug ?

html: That's not a bug. Any value in build/string overrides all default behavior, including build number on the end. You can manually re-add it from the variables at https://conda.io/docs/user-guide/tasks/build-packages/environment-variables.html#environment-variables-set-during-the-build-process which you can use as jinja2 variables. See https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/master/conda.recipe/meta.yaml#L7-L8 for an example
text: That's not a bug.  Any value in build/string overrides all default behavior, including build number on the end.  You can manually re-add it from the variables at https://conda.io/docs/user-guide/tasks/build-packages/environment-variables.html#environment-variables-set-during-the-build-process which you can use as jinja2 variables.  See https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/master/conda.recipe/meta.yaml#L7-L8 for an example

```
test:
  imports:                                                                     
    - imports: MyModule                                                       
      lang: python
```
 However this doesnt work. Is it supposed to be done this way?

text: In your case, your recipe is setting a specific python version.  That's a common mistake.  If you have further recipe problems, I recommend asking in the conda-forge gitter channel.  https://gitter.im/conda-forge/conda-forge.github.io

html:
You should leave the python version unpinned in your recipe, but set it via CLI or by skipping all but the version you want.
build:
  skip:  True   # [py!=36]

html:
@johnkit please refer to docs, specifically this TL;DR:

TL;DR: If you use the new {{ compiler() }} jinja2 to utilize our new compilers, you also must move anything that is not strictly a build tool into your host dependencies. This includes python, python libraries, and any shared libraries that you need to link against in your build. Examples of build tools include any {{ compiler() }}, make, autoconf, perl (for running scripts, not installing perl software), python (for running scripts, not for installing software).
text:
@johnkit please refer to docs, specifically this TL;DR:

> TL;DR: If you use the new {{ compiler() }} jinja2 to utilize our new compilers, you also must move anything that is not strictly a build tool into your host dependencies. This includes python, python libraries, and any shared libraries that you need to link against in your build. Examples of build tools include any {{ compiler() }}, make, autoconf, perl (for running scripts, not installing perl software), python (for running scripts, not for installing software).

I can e.g. ifdefs on some environment variable in my Makefile, but I haven't figured out how to get that env var defined, as of course conda-build is selective (with good reason) about which env vars are passed through. I know about meta.yaml's build:script_env: section, but the associated warnings conda-build emits are unacceptable to me. Related question: conda-build sets a DEBUG_FFLAGS environment variable, but is there a way to choose to use this w/o editing Makefiles? I mean, I'd hope to select it by doing something on the command line when I invoke conda build.

html:
Hello Everyone
I'm building a conda package from a python program that makes use of pickled data files (ie. it relies on data files to work).
Is there a way to include these pickled data files in the conda package and make them accessible to the python code ?
text:
Hello Everyone
I'm building a conda package from a python program that makes use of pickled data files (ie. it relies on data files to work).
Is there a way to include these pickled data files in the conda package and make them accessible to the python code ?

html:
I found a workaround, but it's very convoluted...
In build.sh I copy my data files to a directory

mkdir -p $PREFIX/data/
cp data/quality/mydata.pickle $PREFIX/data/

And in my python code, I check with try/except if I'm executing the program from its directory, or from conda, and then retrieve the correct data location accordingly:

def get_mydata():
    try:
        ret = pickle.load(open("mydata.pickle", 'rb'))
        return(ret)
    except FileNotFoundError:
        cmd = "which mycondapackage"
        res = subprocess.check_output(cmd, shell=True)
        res = res.decode('utf-8').rstrip()
        path = "/".join(res.split("/")[:-2])+"/data/mydata.pickle "
        ret = pickle.load(open(path, 'rb'))
        return(ret)

As I said, very convoluted...
text:
I found a workaround, but it's very convoluted...
In `build.sh` I copy my data files to a directory
```
mkdir -p $PREFIX/data/
cp data/quality/mydata.pickle $PREFIX/data/
```

And in my python code, I check with try/except if I'm executing the program from its directory, or from conda, and then retrieve the correct data location accordingly:
```
def get_mydata():
    try:
        ret = pickle.load(open("mydata.pickle", 'rb'))
        return(ret)
    except FileNotFoundError:
        cmd = "which mycondapackage"
        res = subprocess.check_output(cmd, shell=True)
        res = res.decode('utf-8').rstrip()
        path = "/".join(res.split("/")[:-2])+"/data/mydata.pickle "
        ret = pickle.load(open(path, 'rb'))
        return(ret)
```

As I said, very convoluted...

Hello guys. I'm having trouble with pytest on conda-build.

I want to run tests on the recipe, so I specified pytest --pyargs <pkg_name> as illustrated in the documentation.
But the thing is, the command is ran locally on the test_tmp folder created by conda, which has run_test.py and other files.

So, what happens is, no tests are found, so it fails the build.
Any help?
text:
Hello guys. I'm having trouble with pytest on conda-build. 

I want to run tests on the recipe, so I specified `pytest --pyargs <pkg_name>` as illustrated in the documentation.
But the thing is, the command is ran locally on the `test_tmp` folder created by conda, which has `run_test.py` and other files. 

So, what happens is, no tests are found, so it fails the build.
Any help?

text: I started code to do symlinks in libarchive ( https://github.com/libarchive/libarchive/pull/1030 ) but it's far from finished, finishing would involve directory symlinks, implementing this fallback and readlink style stuff so that final targets get copied when permissions to symlink are not possible. I also wonder if we need package metadata to specify what a package should do if any symlink permission problems happen, ranging from rollback to warning to the default of copying.

text:
Is there a way to translate following thought into a conda package:

I have a package that happened to be called matplotlib, and it offers the user to plot with various different backends, most of which are optional dependencies, because they are needed iff a user wants to use this backend.

So I would like to write a recipe that defines following requirements section:

```yaml
requirements:
   run:
      - package a   # [if backend a is chosen]
      - package b  # [if backend b is chosen]
```

text: @mariusvniekerk that's what I started with, `meta.yaml` was one dir up from the generated client sdk I was trying to package, and `source` `path:` pointed to that "one dir up" location, problem is it picked up all the dot files but also everything under it too.  I now switched `source` `path:` to point to the generated client dir and have copied everything in there (from which `build.sh`copies to `$PREFIX\.`) but what I'm now finding is when built with `--no-include-recipe`, the package includes everything as expected (including the src `.py` files and `docs` folder + `README.*`) and no junk dot files but when installed, it's not installing into the original package name folder that was used before and instead puts `README.*` + `docs` under `/anaconda3` and the submodules under `site-packages`

html: conda packages can be anything.  However, there are conventions.  Conda packages generally are purpose-built.  There are dev packages that include things like headers and setup scripts.  There are runtime packages (the bulk of everything) that are just what you need to run - no examples or docs.  Rarely, there are docs packages or test data packages.

html:
A fix would be to change https://github.com/conda/conda-build/blob/077880c00bf22f0b3cde28e03c977efac0fa9846/conda_build/post.py#L1031
from if not link_path.startswith('.') and link_path != relative_path: to if os.path.isabs(link_path) and link_path != relative_path:
text:
A fix would be to change https://github.com/conda/conda-build/blob/077880c00bf22f0b3cde28e03c977efac0fa9846/conda_build/post.py#L1031
from `if not link_path.startswith('.') and link_path != relative_path:` to `if os.path.isabs(link_path) and link_path != relative_path:`

html: I have no idea what a superbuild folder is. Someone's add-on to conda-build. Recipes are not "generated" in any official way. They are "rendered" with jinja2. There's no limit to what you can specify for target_platform, except that conda may not recognize arbitrary subdirs that you might specify. To be safe, keep to the collection of supported subdirs. https://github.com/conda/conda/blob/4b9d03a1dfbb326f2b7961ae6c53785638e7003f/conda/base/constants.py#L62-L74

text:
Hi guys, 
What do you think to use Black on ``conda-build``? To format the Python code to this format. In my opinion that would be very nice to have
I can open a pull request later formatting the code-base with black and also adding a pre-commit hook to linter the code using black before any commit.

html: That's a great idea. We had agreed internally to do that, but haven't had time. Pre commit hooks are good, but everyone has to set them up themselves. I'm not aware of a way to enforce pre commit hooks on the repository level. I thought it might be better to have a bot that runs black and submits PRS to other people's PR branches instead as a way of enforcing it.
text: That's a great idea. We had agreed internally to do that, but haven't had time. Pre commit hooks are good, but everyone has to set them up themselves. I'm not aware of a way to enforce pre commit hooks on the repository level. I thought it might be better to have a bot that runs black and submits PRS to other people's PR branches instead as a way of enforcing it.

html: Really we should use a symlink here. But AFAIR GCC calls read link on the exe which would follow the symlink, then GCC might read the filename to determine the triplet etc. I know clang does that determination at least. (OK you are talking about binutils instead but it could be similar)!

html: I am building the NetCDF Fortran library as part of a larger recipe and, with --error-overlinking enabled for conda-build, I get an ERROR ... runpaths ['$ORIGIN/.'] found in ... libnetcdff.so.6.2.1 failure. Is this really a problem? Isn't this what conda-build would patchelf it with anyway? Is there something I can do to appease the rpaths checker?
text: I am building the NetCDF Fortran library as part of a larger recipe and, with `--error-overlinking` enabled for `conda-build`, I get an `ERROR ... runpaths ['$ORIGIN/.'] found in ... libnetcdff.so.6.2.1` failure. Is this really a problem? Isn't this what `conda-build` would `patchelf` it with anyway? Is there something I can do to appease the rpaths checker?

html: I was able to overcome this by running patchelf --remove-rpath on the affected executables (I'll try the same for libraries) before they're examined by conda-build. Checking the final executables in the conda .bz2 archive, it does look like conda-build writes back an identical rpath, if I'm not mistaken.
text: I was able to overcome this by running `patchelf --remove-rpath` on the affected executables (I'll try the same for libraries) before they're examined by `conda-build`. Checking the final executables in the conda `.bz2` archive, it does look like `conda-build` writes back an identical rpath, if I'm not mistaken.

html: hi all, I’m seeing build failures from conda build when I execute the build from an environment that includes gcc. This is because the active environment has LDFLAGS set, and the activate script for the _build_env inside of conda-build doesn’t override it. Short of just using env -u LDFLAGS conda build … (which does resolve the problem), is there a way to force conda-build to run in a ‘bare’ environment, or similar, so that my activate environment settings don’t corrupt the build environment?
text: hi all, I’m seeing build failures from `conda build` when I execute the build from an environment that includes gcc. This is because the active environment has `LDFLAGS` set, and the activate script for the `_build_env` inside of `conda-build` doesn’t override it. Short of just using `env -u LDFLAGS conda build …` (which does resolve the problem), is there a way to force `conda-build` to run in a ‘bare’ environment, or similar, so that my activate environment settings don’t corrupt the build environment?

html: I think this can be reproduced by creating an environment that includes gcc_linux-64, activating it without CONDA_BUILD in your environment, then try running conda build … on something that relies on the extra LDFLAGS that get added by activate-gcc_linux-64.sh when CONDA_BUILD=1 is set
text: I think this can be reproduced by creating an environment that includes `gcc_linux-64`, activating it _without_ `CONDA_BUILD` in your environment, then try running `conda build …` on something that relies on the extra `LDFLAGS` that get added by `activate-gcc_linux-64.sh` when `CONDA_BUILD=1` is set

text:
Hi there,

I am trying to create a conda recipe that has this pip requirement: https://pypi.org/project/dm-sonnet/. The requirements section of my meta.yaml currently looks like:

```
requirements:
  build:
    - git
    - cmake
  host:
    - python==3.6.8
    - pip
  run:
    - python==3.6.8
    - absl-py==0.7.1
    - tensorflow==1.14.0
    - dm-sonnet==1.32
```

Unfortunately I'm getting:

```
conda_build.exceptions.DependencyNeedsBuildingError: Unsatisfiable dependencies for platform linux-64: {'dm-sonnet==1.32'}
```

I'm wondering if this is because the `dm-sonnet==1.32` package is not available within any conda channel (as far as I am aware)? Can conda build pull the dependency from PyPi?

(Alternatively, can I ask my conda build to install all pip requirements defined in a requirements.txt?)

Many thanks!

html: gabm I asked in the conda-forge channel but got pointed to conda-build. There is a systematic issue with conda-build when cross-compiling: if the package hashes are identical for two packages in build- and host-environment, then the architectures get mixed up. I experienced that a year ago already and now again with the ncurses package from conda-forge. I created an issue here: conda/conda-build#3155
text: `gabm` I asked in the conda-forge channel but got pointed to conda-build. I experienced that a year ago already and now again with the ncurses package from conda-forge. I created an issue here: https://github.com/conda/conda-build/issues/3155

Additionally, suppose that the first makes some file, and then the second updates that same file. When I install them, conda will give me warnings about things getting clobbered. Is there a way to tell conda/conda-build that some directories/files are OK to clobber?
text: I have a random question for the room. Suppose I have two recipes with the second depending on the first. Additionally, suppose that the first makes some file, and then the second updates that same file. When I install them, conda will give me warnings about things getting clobbered. html: not right now.  That would require a change in both conda and conda-build.  I'm not sure it would be feasible to generalize it.  Is it always ok to clobber both ways, or only one way?  What if more than two packages have that file?  What's the priority then?

text:
hi all, I’m trying to build `htcondor`, and conda-build is erroring with stuff like this:
```
ERROR (htcondor,bin/condor_test_match): runpaths ['$ORIGIN/../lib'] found in <_h_env_path>/bin/condor_test_match
```
is there a way to ignore these errors, or should I actually try and find the place in the build that adds that to the rpath and remove it?

html: Hey @duncanmmacleod Ideally, yes, that would be optional. RUNPATH vs RPATH is an important distinction in a few ways and can require different handling of transitivity (reference: https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/eglibc/+bug/1253638 - though closed, I believe the technical facts as reported are correct and worrisome) so if the build system is already aware of the distinction best to try to go through its mechanisms as that is most likely to work best. Ecosystem-wise, RPATH gives us much better security guarantees as LD_LIBRARY_PATH can be an attack (and bug) vector.
text: Hey @duncanmmacleod Ideally, yes, that would be optional. RUNPATH vs RPATH is an important distinction in a few ways and can require different handling of transitivity (reference: https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/eglibc/+bug/1253638 - though closed, I believe the technical facts as reported are correct and worrisome) so if the build system is already aware of the distinction best to try to go through its mechanisms as that is most likely to work best. Ecosystem-wise, RPATH gives us much better security guarantees as LD_LIBRARY_PATH can be an attack (and bug) vector.

html: thanks @mingwandroid. So, it turns out it’s conda-build that is adding ORIGIN runpaths to my code here. I’m not a linking expert, so I presume that conda-build would only do this to prevent me having used a crappy rpath further upstream in my build?
text: thanks @mingwandroid. So, it turns out it’s conda-build that is adding ORIGIN runpaths to my code [here](https://github.com/conda/conda-build/blob/f2f408b6501ac59455d0ebd54c1065e292439d99/conda_build/post.py#L508). I’m not a linking expert, so I presume that conda-build would only do this to prevent me having used a crappy rpath further upstream in my build?

html: digging deeper (adding print statements to conda_build.post), it looks like my binary is being installed with an absolute rpath of {prefix}/lib, which conda-build is replacing with $ORIGIN/../lib in one function, then failing in the next because it won’t accept $ORIGIN/../lib. I’ll still try and see where my build is injecting the absolute rpath and if it can be removed (its a cmake project, there will be a way)

html: ok, I am now convinced that the issue here is that my build is setting runpath, and conda-build doesn’t like it. conda-build is replacing exising rpath entries with ORIGIN paths, which it is ok with later, but the but not runpath, hence the error. patchelf doesn’t seem to make any distinction between the two, so calling patchelf --force-rpath --set-rpath … will replace the existing RUNPATH on my binary with another RUNPATH - maybe that’s what it is supposed to do
text: ok, I am now convinced that the issue here is that my build is setting runpath, and conda-build doesn’t like it. conda-build is replacing exising **rpath** entries with `ORIGIN` paths, which it is ok with later, but the but not `runpath`, hence the error. `patchelf` doesn’t seem to make any distinction between the two, so calling `patchelf --force-rpath --set-rpath …` will replace the existing `RUNPATH` on my binary with another `RUNPATH` - maybe that’s what it is supposed to do

on another topic, is there a way to disentagle a recipe called package with an output of the same name?

I would like to have a recipe where the top-level build gets split up into subpackages using outputs/files, where one output has the same name as the top-level package. That output’s requirements are a proper subset of the overall build requirements, but conda-build seems to preferentially select the output’s requirements list over the top-level list when building the environments to use for the top-level build stage. Is that bug, or am I just using conda-build and outputs incorrectly?
text:

html: notice that for really long env names, conda is putting in /usr/bin/env for the prefix
text: notice that for really long env names, conda is putting in `/usr/bin/env ` for the prefix

html: all of the env names when running conda build exceeed ~128 characters
text: all of the env names when running conda build exceeed ~128 characters

html: and hence they get set to /usr/bin/env

html: and thus on mac they trigger SIP behavior
text: and thus on mac they trigger SIP behavior

html: One way around this would be to map every env to a short random hash.

html: https://github.com/conda/conda/blob/4.7.12/conda/core/portability.py#L155-L175 is replacing the long shebang lines for portability. Most platforms/distribution have some limit on the length of the shebang and using #!/usr/bin/env python in those cases. Adding a configuration option to override this rewrite would be reasonable.
text: https://github.com/conda/conda/blob/4.7.12/conda/core/portability.py#L155-L175 is replacing the long shebang lines for portability. Adding a configuration option to override this rewrite would be reasonable.

html:
My understanding is that the sbin folder on Linux systems is for segregating binaries meant to be run by privileged users. (generally speaking, sysadmins)

But conda is a generic package manager and doesn't make such distinctions, so the need for segregating binaries doesn't make much sense here.

html: hey! I have a random question that I think needs some conda build expertise. I am working on a build where I have 1) merged the hist and build envs and 2) am running tests using pytest and co during the build. What I am finding is that for some of the pytest infrastructure, which are noarch packages, that .pyc files are being left in the final package. These don't have the prefix replaced and so are causing downstream errors. Is this a weird corner case or are there conda build settings I should be using?

{% set setup = load_setup_py_data(setup_file='../setup.py', from_recipe_dir=True) %}

package:
  name: {{ setup.get('name') }}
  version: {{ setup.get('version') }}

source:
  path: ../

build:
  noarch: python
  number: {{ environ.get('BUILD_NUMBER', 0) }}
  pin_depends: record

requirements:
  # needs to match what's in setup.py, but can't get jinja to work for lists
  build:
    - pytest-runner
    - flake8
    - sphinx
    - wheel
  host:
    - python
  run:
    - attrs >=19.1
    - CacheControl
    - geopy
    - iso8601
    - lazy-object-proxy >=1.4, <2
    - requests >=2.22, <3
  run_constrained:
    - pandas >=0.25
  test:
    imports:
      - srf_client
    source_files:
      - ../tests
    requires:
      - pytest >=5
      - pytest-mock
      - requests-mock

about:
  home: {{ setup.get('url') }}
  summary: {{ setup.get('description') }}

extra:
  {{ setup }}

```yaml
  pin_depends: record
```
  script: "{{ PYTHON }} -m pip install . -vv"

requirements:
  # needs to match what's in setup.py, but can't get jinja to work for lists
  host:
    - pytest-runner
    - flake8
    - sphinx
    - wheel
    - python
    - pip
  run:
    - attrs >=19.1
    - CacheControl
    - geopy
    - iso8601
    - lazy-object-proxy >=1.4, <2
    - requests >=2.22, <3
    - pandas >=0.25
test:
  imports:
    - srf_client

about:
  home: www.yourproject.com
  summary: "SUMMARY HERE"



html: Ok. There's probably a bug or at least unintuitive behavior here. I still recommend using croot instead of output folder. Output folder was written for our in house build system and is not something that most people use. It looks like you are trying to bend conda build's folder structure into your own incompatible one, possibly for better isolation?  If you'd like to figure out why this behavior is going south, go for it, but my advice would be to use the more established conda build croot and script the movement of files from that croot into your dist folder, or perhaps symlink things somehow.
text: Ok. There's probably a bug or at least unintuitive behavior here. I still recommend using croot instead of output folder. Output folder was written for our in house build system and is not something that most people use. It looks like you are trying to bend conda build's folder structure into your own incompatible one, possibly for better isolation?  If you'd like to figure out why this behavior is going south, go for it, but my advice would be to use the more established conda build croot and script the movement of files from that croot into your dist folder, or perhaps symlink things somehow.

html:
Can a package support both a post-link.sh and post-link.bat file?

Yes, I believe conda is able to handle such package. I can't comment on the recipe part though, i.e., how conda-build handles this case.
However, I would not recommend what you are trying to do. Better avoid post-link/pre-unlink scripts altogether or keep them in a separate non-noarch package, i.e., create two dependent packages. Do one of the following:

  1. Figure out if you really need those scripts or if you can prepare the package during build time in such a way that you can just omit them.
  2. Create package your-package that has a requirements/run on your-package-link-scripts:
    Put the post-link/pre-unlink scripts in your-package-link-scripts.
    your-package can be noarch but also depend on non-noarch packages, so this is fine.
  3. Make your-package not noarch, put only the scripts inside this package and add a requirements/run on a noarch package your-package-core:
    Same as 2. just with reversed dependencies.

I recommend to try 1. and if that is really not feasible, do 2. then.

on Windows we need all 3 of bat, sh and ps1

I think you were thinking of (de-)activate scripts here ;). For post-link/pre-unlink, conda only supports .sh and .bat and also only executes the latter, but not the former, on Windows.

interfacing with the conda python package directly, eg: "from conda_build import api" --- is conda_build separate from conda-build?

conda_build is the name of the Python package that is contained in the Conda package conda-build. Python packages cannot contain dashes and thus those are commonly replaced by underscores. So no, they are not separate.
However, conda is a separate package, meaning you are "interfacing with the conda conda_build python package` ;).

I just noticed this: "[...]" --- though it only mentions preprocess-selectors could one derive from that it also means the post-link/pre-unlink scripts?

Can you open up an issue for the docs to also recommend not to use those scripts on noarch packages? That would be helpful!
text:
> Can a package support both a post-link.sh and post-link.bat file?

Yes, I believe `conda` is able to handle such *package*. I can't comment on the *recipe* part though, i.e., how `conda-build` handles this case.
**However, I would not recommend** what you are trying to do. Better avoid post-link/pre-unlink scripts altogether or keep them in a separate non-`noarch` package, i.e., create two dependent packages. Do one of the following:
1. Figure out if you really need those scripts or if you can prepare the package during build time in such a way that you can just omit them.
2. Create package `your-package` that has a `requirements/run` on `your-package-link-scripts`:
   Put the post-link/pre-unlink scripts in `your-package-link-scripts`.
   `your-package` can be `noarch` but also depend on non-`noarch` packages, so this is fine.
3. Make `your-package` not `noarch`, put only the scripts inside this package and add a `requirements/run` on a `noarch` package `your-package-core`:
   Same as 2. just with reversed dependencies.

I recommend to try 1. and if that is really not feasible, do 2. then.

> on Windows we need all 3 of bat, sh and ps1

I think you were thinking of (de-)activate scripts here ;). For post-link/pre-unlink, `conda` only supports `.sh` and `.bat` and also only executes the latter, but not the former, on Windows.

> interfacing with the conda python package directly, eg: "from conda_build import api" --- is conda_build separate from conda-build?

`conda_build` is the name of the Python package that is contained in the Conda package `conda-build`. Python packages cannot contain dashes and thus those are commonly replaced by underscores. So no, they are not separate.
However, `conda` is a separate package, meaning you are "interfacing with the ~~conda~~ conda_build python package` ;).

> I just noticed this: "\[...\]" --- though it only mentions preprocess-selectors could one derive from that it also means the post-link/pre-unlink scripts?

Can you open up an issue for the docs to also recommend not to use those scripts on `noarch` packages? That would be helpful!

You're pretty much on point with the terminology ;).

so I just want to make sure I'm following along correctly with what you're suggesting
[...]
I'm not sure what I'm saying makes sense.

I think you do and it does!

It's totally up to you whether you create separate recipes or use "subpackages" via outputs in a single recipe. Use whatever seems more convenient to you. The output, i.e., the built Conda packages that you distribute to your users, is likely identical no matter how many recipes you use. Recipes are only a build-side thing, i.e., conda-build's input. The package manager itself, conda, does not know/care at all about the recipes but just about conda-build's output, i.e., the built Conda packages!

I think you do and it does!

It's totally up to you whether you create separate recipes or use "subpackages" via `outputs` in a single recipe. Use whatever seems more convenient to you. The output, i.e., the built Conda packages that you distribute to your users, is likely identical no matter how many recipes you use. Recipes are only a build-side thing, i.e., `conda-build`'s input. The package manager itself, `conda`, does not know/care at all about the recipes but just about `conda-build`'s output, i.e., the built Conda packages!

html:
In this case I would probably skip the recipe's main build/script and/or build.sh and only do a separate script for the subpackages, e.g. something like:

package:
  name: your-package-meta
  version: some.version

outputs:
  - name: your-package
    build:
      noarch: generic
      script: build-your-package.sh
      requirements:
        run:
          - {{ pin_subpackage("your-package-link-scripts") }}  # possibly adjust the pinning here
  - name: your-package-link-scripts
    build:
      post-link: your-package-link-scripts-post-link.sh  # maybe this is not needed

IIRC, you could leave out build/post-link: your-package-link-scripts-post-link.sh since conda-build will look for <package-name>-post-link.sh scripts automatically. Not sure though. I'd say just try it out and add proper tests for the subpackage to make sure it built fine and included the correct link scripts.

But I'm much more knowledgeable about conda than conda-build, esp. when it comes to howoutputsare handled in detail. Maybe someone better versed withconda-build` can answer that.
text:
In this case I would probably skip the recipe's main `build/script` and/or `build.sh` and only do a separate script  for the subpackages, e.g. something like:
```
package:
  name: your-package-meta
  version: some.version

outputs:
  - name: your-package
    build:
      noarch: generic
      script: build-your-package.sh
      requirements:
        run:
          - {{ pin_subpackage("your-package-link-scripts") }}  # possibly adjust the pinning here
  - name: your-package-link-scripts
    build:
      post-link: your-package-link-scripts-post-link.sh  # maybe this is not needed
```
IIRC, you could leave out `build/post-link: your-package-link-scripts-post-link.sh` since `conda-build` will look for `<package-name>-post-link.sh` scripts automatically. Not sure though. I'd say just try it out and add proper tests for the subpackage to make sure it built fine and included the correct link scripts.

But I'm much more knowledgeable about `conda` than `conda-build, esp. when it comes to how `outputs` are handled in detail. Maybe someone better versed with `conda-build` can answer that.

Yes, I might not have been precise here: You would create builds for the `-link-scripts` package for all systems/`subdir`s you want to support separately, e.g., create one for `linux-64`, `osx-64`, `win-64` (depending on the content, the Linux and macOS one might be completely identical).

text: Hey guys, I am very new to conda. This may be a basic question but I hope that someone can help me. I could successfully build the conda package locally. But when I used that local tar.bz2 file to install the package in an conda environment, all the dependencies (listed in the meta.yaml file under requirements-run) were not installed together with the packages. Using conda list to check the installed pkgs, I cannot find those dependencies except the main package. Could anyone help me please? Many thanks!!!!

html: It's a longstanding bug/feature of conda that it ignores dependencies when you install packages via files directly. It is not clear if/when that'll change. You can use conda-index which is part of conda-build to create a local repository index from which you can install packages from (via conda create --channel=/path/to/local/repo ...).
text: It's a longstanding bug/feature of `conda` that it ignores dependencies when you install packages via files directly. It is not clear if/when that'll change. You can use `conda-index` which is part of `conda-build` to create a local repository index from which you can install packages from (via `conda create --channel=/path/to/local/repo ...`).

dependency to `boost-python` (i.e. the `py-boost` `conda` package). I
try to build my package locally (on `LiNuX` or on `Mac`) and using the

  detects the library but the build fails because the header
  `boost/python.hpp` is missing). However, my `docker` builds succeed.
- If I put `py-boost` in the `build` section, my local build succeeds,
  but my `docker` builds fail.

I am a bit stuck here, so any help would be appreciated. My recipe can
be found here:

html: The problem with CMake is that it does a load of hidden things on your behalf, presumably to make life easier. Unfortunately it's also "greedy" by which I mean it's not at all hermetic, it's happy to rummage around anywhere on your system looking for headers and libs (and things that look like them) that might work. It's often wrong, and that makes reproducible builds almost a non-starter (unless you add something like Docker in to the mix)

@mingwandroid I just add this in my build.sh file:

ls ${PREFIX}
ls ${PREFIX}/lib
ls ${BUILD_PREFIX}/include
ls ${PREFIX}/include

I found that:

  • ${PREFIX}does not contain a subdirectory called include
  • ${BUILD_PREFIX}does contain a subdirectory called include with in particular the boost-python headers
  • ${PREFIX}/libdoes contain the shared library associated with boost-python

This is highly uncommon (and questionnable), no wonder that cmake can't find its way without more help. So, in my case, a workaround would be (not tested yet) to specify BOOST_INCLUDEDIRS to ${BUILD_PREFIX} when calling cmake.
text:
@mingwandroid I just add this in my `build.sh` file:

~~~~
ls ${PREFIX}
ls ${PREFIX}/lib
ls ${BUILD_PREFIX}/include
ls ${PREFIX}/include
~~~~

I found that:

- `${PREFIX}`does not contain a subdirectory called `include`
- `${BUILD_PREFIX}`does contain a subdirectory called `include` with in particular the `boost-python` headers
- `${PREFIX}/lib`does contain the shared library associated with `boost-python`

This is highly uncommon (and questionnable), no wonder that `cmake` can't find its way without more help. So, in my case, a workaround would be (not tested yet) to specify `BOOST_INCLUDEDIRS` to `${BUILD_PREFIX}` when calling `cmake`.

html: Will Conda build allow cyclic dependency in "run" section? For example, A has "B" under the running dependency and B has A in the running dependency. How will conda solve the installation of both packages? Thanks!
text: Will Conda build allow cyclic dependency in "run" section? For example, A has "B" under the running dependency and B has A in the running dependency. How will conda solve the installation of both packages? Thanks!

html: If the cycle is only in the run section and not the host/build sections than conda-build can build the the two in one process.  The process is 1. Build A, 2. Build B, 3. Test A, 4. Test B.

And is it possible to cross-compile Python packages?

html:
@mingwandroid I finally made a patch to my project to use CXXFLAGS and CFLAGS as defined by conda-build.

I found out that cmake correctly detects py-boost (i.e. Boost_INCLUDEDIRS has the correct value which is $PREFIX/include) but the path toward the header is discarded by cmake' command target_include_directories, probably because it contains a reference to $PREFIX.

Note that I had to solve another related issue. The path to the python headers are not declared in CXXFLAGS and CFLAGS, so I had to add them explicitely. Again, this path was correctly found by cmake (i.e. PYTHON_INCLUDEDIRS has the correct value which is $PREFIX/python3.7m/include) but discarded by target_include_directories.

Anyway, thanks for your help.
text:
@mingwandroid I finally made a patch to my project to use `CXXFLAGS` and `CFLAGS` as defined by `conda-build`.

 I found out that `cmake` correctly detects `py-boost` (i.e. `Boost_INCLUDEDIRS` has the correct value which is `$PREFIX/include`) but the path toward the header is discarded by `cmake`' command `target_include_directories`, probably because it contains a reference to `$PREFIX`. 

Note that I had to solve another related issue. The path to the python headers are **not** declared in `CXXFLAGS` and `CFLAGS`, so I had to add them explicitely. Again, this path was correctly found by `cmake`  (i.e. `PYTHON_INCLUDEDIRS` has the correct value which is `$PREFIX/python3.7m/include`) but discarded by `target_include_directories`.

 Anyway, thanks for your help.

html: Those locations should be the same if python is in host. There will be two site-packages directory if python is in both build and host. I believe SP_DIR will point at the host location.
text: Those locations should be the same if `python` is in host.  There will be two site-packages directory if `python` is in both `build` and `host`.  I believe `SP_DIR` will point at the `host` location.
